newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria to import 100,000 tonnes of U.S. grain.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria to import 100,000 tonnes of U.S. grain.

text.p: Bulgaria expects to import around 100,000 tonnes of grain worth $25 million from the U.S., trade minister Atanas Paparizov said on Wednesday.
"The 100,000 tonnes of grain, which will be imported under a U.S. government programme, will replenish the state reserves," Paparizov told a news conference.
Bulgaria appointed the state grain company Zarno as importer and the state-owned Bulbank to service the deal.

Facing an acute grain shortage due to excessive exports last year and a poor harvest this season, Bulgaria said earlier that it would import large quantities of wheat to cover human consumption and fodder needs.

Sofia also planned to apply for funds from a Compensatory and Contingency Financing Facility (CCFF) extended by the International Monetary Fund to countries with short-term balance of payments problems for reasons beyond their control, said Paparizov.
The government has already lifted all customs duties and fees on grain imports from the beginning of this year.
However, only 22 percent of the 450,000 tonnes of bread wheat permitted for import without duties had been covered, said Paparisov.
Bulgaria's cabinet agreed two weeks ago the swap 20,000 tonnes of sunflower oil for grain.
